animeshtrivedi opened a new pull request #3032: ARROW-3493: [Java] Make sure bound checks are off
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3032
 
 
   As discussed previously on the mailing list, I found
   that the bound checks have significant performance
   penalty. This commit:
   * renames the property from "drill.enable_unsafe_memory_access"
     to "arrow.check_unsafe_memory_access"
   * set the default value to false
   
   For somehow doing debugging, they can set it back to true.
   
   Signed-off-by: Animesh Trivedi <atrivedi@apache.org>

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3032#issuecomment-441676862
 
 
   I'm -1 on the change of the default to no bounds checking. This will likely cause new users of Arrow to get JVM crashes instead of exceptions and isn't something most JVM developers are comfortable with. The name change is good.

animeshtrivedi commented on issue #3032: ARROW-3493: [Java] Make sure bound checks are off
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3032#issuecomment-441681123
 
 
   Hi @jacques-n - I understand your concern. However, I think access to unsafe buffers are all done inside the arrow implementation. So if there is a crash, then there is a bug in our code (not the user, if they are using the Arrow APIs). We need to fix that. 
   
   Other option would be to keep the checks, but document this property "somewhere" so that any one who comes across Java documentation need to understand this immediately. It took me a while to find this out, and i think it should not be this hard.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3032#issuecomment-441711443
 
 
   The public apis of Arrow allow unsafe access if this is disabled. You can simply call IntVector.getInt(Integer.MAX_VALUE) if bounds checks are off and you'll have a crash. fields.description:
According to [~atrivedi], BOUNDS_CHECKING_ENABLED has significant implication on performance.

We should document this better and maybe revisit the default value. 

https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/java/memory/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/memory/BoundsChecking.java

comments.body:
So, I propose that we

i) rename the variable from "drill.enable_unsafe_memory_access" to "arrow.enable_unsafe_memory_access"

ii) set the default to false. This can be enabled if user explicitly wants to debug and check ranges. 

iii) document this flag (and perhaps the netty one too) in the Java user documentation. 

If we agree then I will open a pull request.
